awd_titl_txt: NMR-Based Approaches for Investigating Protein-Surface Interactions
awd_abstract_narration:
The overall goal of this project is to determine the mechanism for how proteins interact with nanoparticle surfaces. Protein-surface interactions are a significant consideration in many scientific fields, from engineering protein-functionalized nanoparticles (NPs) to preventing the attachment of marine organisms to ship hulls. Understanding the mechanism of interaction may lead to better strategies for controlling protein-surface interactions. The project will focus specifically on gold nanoparticles. A better understanding of protein-gold nanoparticle interactions could lead to more sensitive ways to detect molecules in the environment. The project is expected to produce two important results. First, it will lead to better predictive models for understanding why proteins interact with gold nanoparticles. Second, it will reveal the structural characteristics of proteins once they bind. In addition, the project supports a summer training camp for undergraduate researchers in the southeast. This program, called Biochemistry Boot Camp, trains students how to use computational tools for interpreting protein structure and function. These tools are used not only in this research project, but many others as well.

This project aims to study the forces involved in protein adsorption using novel NMR-based approaches for monitoring protein interactions with gold nanoparticles. Nanoparticles are useful for studying protein-surface interactions because of their extremely high surface to volume ratio. This project will characterize the biophysical forces involved in multiple protein adsorption to gold nanoparticle surfaces, using novel approaches to monitor adsorption in real time. Specifically, it will identify the structural properties that control adsorption kinetics and thermodynamics to gold nanoparticles. The project will also investigate the structure of several small model proteins after they have attached to the gold nanoparticle surface. Thus, this work addresses one of the key challenges in the field of nanotechnology while laying the groundwork for new investigations into generalized protein-surface interactions. In addition, the project is expected to result in new NMR-based tools for studying proteins on other types of surfaces. 

This award is jointly funded by the Molecular Biophysics Cluster of the Division of Cellular and Molecular Biosciences and the OIA/EPSCoR.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
This research project focused on the behavior of proteins when exposed to gold nanoparticle surfaces. Gold nanoparticles are an attractive material for detecting other chemicals and as drug-delivery vehicles. However, whenever gold nanoparticles are exposed to biological fluids, they become coated with proteins, and a "corona" of adsorbed proteins forms around the nanoparticle. The goal was to use nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy to understand the physical mechanism behind this behavior and identify the key protein features that lead to adsorption.

Intellectual Merit: Early in the project, it was identified that the rate at which proteins collide with nanoparticles was a significant factor in their interactions. These stochastic collisions are classified as "kinetic control," which is contrasted with a model of "thermodynamic control," where the most stable protein-surface interactions dominate. The research identified that "whoever gets to the surface first wins." Because of this, a major focus of the research was on strategies for characterizing competition between multiple proteins. Here is where NMR was instrumental in the research: Using selective labeling strategies, it was possible to differentiate multiple proteins in a single sample, enabling real-time monitoring of competition between proteins. A method for rapidly monitoring protein-surface interactions was also developed. This method has a timescale resolution of approximately 5 minutes. Finally, a new external NMR reference that enabled absolute protein quantitation was created. Together, these advances were leveraged to develop a predictive model for identifying the surface orientation of adsorbed proteins on a nanoparticle surface. Moreover, the study of adsorption in blood serum was investigated, and it was found that the serum proteins can significantly slow the adsorption of a target protein. Finally, the concepts explored in this research led to the development of a new temperature-responsive gold nanoparticle that could efficiently convert light energy into heat (photothermal conversion). Such a material could be useful for treating cancer or ablating biofilms.

Broader Impacts: Numerous undergraduate (17) and graduate student (10) researchers played a role in this research, as well as two postdoctoral scholars. To date, two students participating in this project have obtained an M.S. degree, and four students have obtained their Ph.D. A fifth student is expected to defend their Ph.D. dissertation in early 2024. Students participating in this research have participated in industrial internships and are currently working at chemical and pharmaceutical companies throughout the US. Others have gone on to complete postdocs at leading research institutions. During this project, the Biochemistry Boot Camp exposed over 200 undergraduate and early graduate students to essential computational biophysics and bioinformatics topics. Together, videos of Biochemistry Boot Camp posted to YouTube have obtained over 1,500 views, and the program remains a popular summer experience. Finally, this research has led to new concepts relevant to gold nanoparticles and other adsorption phenomena.

In summary, this work has successfully contributed to understanding the biophysical principles involved in protein adsorption to gold nanoparticles, and it has led to novel methodologies whereby NMR can be used to understand protein-nanoparticle interactions. The work has trained scientists for the workforce and led to the education of students at all levels.


Last Modified: 09/10/2023
Modified by: Nicholas C Fitzkee
